\\n\"}"}}],"org.ekstep.text":[{"x":12.36,"y":23.7,"minWidth":20,"w":59.83,"maxWidth":500,"fill":"#000000","fontStyle":"normal","fontWeight":"normal","stroke":"rgba(255, 255, 255, 0)","strokeWidth":1,"opacity":1,"editable":false,"version":"V2","offsetY":0.04,"h":70.31,"rotate":0,"textType":"text","lineHeight":1,"z-index":1,"font":"NotoSans","fontsize":48,"weight":"","id":"39557220-cc87-43e1-b118-e088a4496300","config":{"__cdata":"{\"opacity\":100,\"strokeWidth\":1,\"stroke\":\"rgba(255, 255, 255, 0)\",\"autoplay\":false,\"visible\":true,\"text\":\"The name of the range derives from the Sanskrit Himā-laya , from himá and ā-laya They are now known as the \\\"Himalaya Mountains\\\", usually shortened to the \\\"Himalayas\\\". Formerly, they were described in the singular as the \\\"Himalaya\\\". This was also previously transcribed \\\"Himmaleh\\\", as in Emily Dickinson's poetry and Henry David Thoreau's essays.\\n\\nThe mountains are known as the Himālaya in Nepali and Hindi the Himalaya (ཧི་མ་ལ་ཡ་) or 'The Land of Snow in Tibetan, the Hamaleh Mountain Range in Urdu and the Ximalaya Mountain Range in Chinese.\",\"color\":\"#000000\",\"fontfamily\":\"NotoSans\",\"fontsize\":18,\"fontweight\":false,\"fontstyle\":false,\"align\":\"left\"}"}}]},{"x":0,"y":0,"w":100,"h":100,"id":"28123cbc-2009-4c13-8779-836a14216491","rotate":null,"config":{"__cdata":"{\"opacity\":100,\"strokeWidth\":1,\"stroke\":\"rgba(255, 255, 255, 0)\",\"autoplay\":false,\"visible\":true,\"color\":\"#FFFFFF\",\"genieControls\":false,\"instructions\":\"\"}"},"param":[{"name":"previous","value":"49632469-806d-4c87-8385-1db7d8a00847"},{"name":"next","value":"3942b521-ac30-43d2-b13e-5c64b58a63e4"}],"manifest":{"media":[{"assetId":"do_2125443074628976641141"}]},"org.ekstep.text":[{"x":22.22,"y":26.42,"minWidth":20,"w":35,"maxWidth":500,"fill":"#000000","fontStyle":"normal","fontWeight":"normal","stroke":"rgba(255, 255, 255, 0)","strokeWidth":1,"opacity":1,"editable":false,"version":"V2","offsetY":0.04,"h":5.02,"rotate":0,"textType":"text","lineHeight":1,"z-index":0,"font":"NotoSans","fontsize":48,"weight":"","id":"3531a0c8-d1a3-473e-879e-b58785788b34","config":{"__cdata":"{\"opacity\":100,\"strokeWidth\":1,\"stroke\":\"rgba(255, 255, 255, 0)\",\"autoplay\":false,\"visible\":true,\"text\":\"Click me to listen to audio!!!!\",\"color\":\"#000000\",\"fontfamily\":\"NotoSans\",\"fontsize\":18,\"fontweight\":false,\"fontstyle\":false,\"align\":\"left\"}"},"event":[{"type":"click","action":[{"id":"5c04c922-0a3d-4d9a-a945-c75dd89d2036","type":"command","command":"togglePlay","asset":"do_2125443074628976641141","name":"(3D AUDIO) Faded - Some of the world's major rivers—the Indus, the Ganges and the Tsangpo-Brahmaputra—rise in the Himalayas, and their combined drainage basin is home to roughly 600 million people. The Himalayas have a profound effect on the climate of the region, helping to keep the monsoon rains on the Indian plain and limiting rainfall on the Tibetan plateau. The Himalayas have profoundly shaped the cultures of the Indian subcontinent; many Himalayan peaks are sacred in Hinduism and Buddhism.\",\"color\":\"#000000\",\"fontfamily\":\"NotoSans\",\"fontsize\":18,\"fontweight\":false,\"fontstyle\":false,\"align\":\"left\"}"}}]},{"x":0,"y":0,"w":100,"h":100,"id":"62c405b1-5a39-4389-84aa-4917508972a2","rotate":null,"config":{"__cdata":"{\"opacity\":100,\"strokeWidth\":1,\"stroke\":\"rgba(255,
